docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS FROM LOWER TO HIGHER COURT [ss 139–144]

heading.title: PART 9 TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS BETWEEN COURTS [ss 139–154]
DIVISION 1 TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS FROM LOWER TO HIGHER COURT [ss 139–144]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 9 TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS BETWEEN COURTS [ss 139–154]
DIVISION 1 TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS FROM LOWER TO HIGHER COURT [ss 139–144]

leg:heading.title: TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS FROM LOWER TO HIGHER COURT [ss 139–144]

p.text: In this Division:
means the court to which proceedings are transferred, or are proposed to be transferred, by a transfer order.
means the court from which proceedings are transferred, or are proposed to be transferred, by a transfer order.
means an order referred to in section 140 .
Legislation cited in [s 139.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 139–153.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 140] s 140 Transfer of proceedings to higher court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 145; Act No 11 1970, section 21B)

leg:heading.title: Transfer of proceedings to higher court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 145; Act No 11 1970, section 21B)

p.text: The Supreme Court may, of its own motion or on application by a party to proceedings before the District Court or the Local Court, order that the proceedings, including any cross-claim in the proceedings, be transferred to the Supreme Court.
[subs (1) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]

The District Court may, of its own motion or on application by a party to proceedings before the Local Court, order that the proceedings, including any cross-claim in the proceedings, be transferred to the District Court.
[subs (2) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
Proceedings in the District Court on a claim for damages arising from personal injury or death are not to be transferred to the Supreme Court under this section unless the Supreme Court is satisfied:
in the case of a motor accident claim or a workplace injury damages claim:
that the amount to be awarded to the plaintiff, if successful, is likely to be more than $1,000,000, and
that the case involves complex legal issues or issues of general public importance, or
in any other case:
that the amount to be awarded to the plaintiff, if successful, is likely to exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court, or
that there is other sufficient reason for hearing the proceedings in the Supreme Court.

Proceedings in the Local Court are not to be transferred to a higher court under this section unless the higher court is satisfied that there is sufficient reason for hearing the proceedings in the higher court.
[subs (4) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
This section extends to proceedings that have been transferred to the District Court or the Local Court pursuant to a previous transfer order under this Division or under Division 2 or 3.
[subs (5) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
Legislation cited in [s 140.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 140(3).

Subject to the specific limitations in s 140(3) that apply to the transfer of personal injury proceedings in the District Court, the court has a discretionary power to make the orders sought. An order may be made whenever the transferor court considers that removal of the proceedings is appropriate, in the light of the particular circumstances of the proceedings and the matters in issue: McCormick v BP Australia Ltd [2003] NSWSC 690; BC200304267 at [20] . The fundamental consideration is whether there is “sufficient cause” for the transfer to be made. That criterion permits a wide range of considerations and involves discretionary, indeed impressionistic, evaluation: Sanderson Motors Pty Ltd v Kirby [2000] NSWSC 924; BC200005871 at [3], [4] ; Banks v Hollingsworth [1893] 1 QB 442 ; Challis v Watson [1913] 1 KB 547 ; Lee v Proprietors of Hay's Wharf Ltd [1940] 2 KB 306; [1940] 3 All ER 282 ; Ritchie v Gumley (1954) 55 SR (NSW) 334; 72 WN (NSW) 298 ; Ex parte McIntosh; Re Frey (1958) 75 WN (NSW) 519 ; George Pearse Pty Ltd v O'Flynn [1963] NSWR 102; [1962] SR (NSW) 400 ; Ex parte Vigilant Finance (NSW) Pty Ltd; Re Cameron Smith [1964] NSWR 1282 . The discretion to transfer does not depend on the proceedings falling within the jurisdictional limits of the lower court: KBRV Resort Operations Pty Ltd (t/as Kingfisher Bay Resort & Village) v Chilcott (2001) 51 NSWLR 516 at 526; [2001] NSWCA 116; BC200102124 . Indeed, and as the wording of the section implies, the absence of jurisdiction provides a reason for transfer: Ex parte Delponte; Re Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1468 , per Asprey J; Webb v Kunich (NSWSC, Cohen M in Eq, No 3172/78, 23 October 1978, unreported, BC7800013) (claim for return of deposit under s 55(2A) of the Conveyancing Act 1919). Chilcott v KBRV Resort Operations Pty Ltd (t/as Kingfisher Bay Resort & Village) (1999) 29 MVR 225; [1999] NSWSC 633; BC9904271 affirmed on this point KBRV Resort Operations Pty Ltd (t/as Kingfisher Bay Resort & Village) v Chilcott (2001) 51 NSWLR 516 at 526; [2001] NSWCA 116; BC200102124 .

level.toc-caption: [s 140.10] Personal injury proceedings in the District Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 140.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 140(3).

heading.title: Personal injury proceedings in the District Court

p.text: The power to transfer personal injury proceedings from the District Court to the Supreme Court is restricted by the terms of s 140(3) of the CPA. In determining whether it is satisfied the likely award will exceed the relevant limit the relevant inquiry is as to the amount the plaintiff could reasonably expect to obtain: see Ex parte Delponte; Re Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1468 . In making that assessment the court does not try the issue. The fact that there is apparently acceptable evidence supporting the plaintiff's claim may suffice to provide the requisite satisfaction: Bowditch v Hoey (NSWSC, Greenwood M, 6 February 1997, unreported, BC9700198). But where the likely amount of the claim is contentious the statutory criterion requires the court to be affirmatively satisfied that any award of damages is likely to exceed the relevant limit: Younes v QIC Ltd t/as Westpoint Blacktown [2012] NSWSC 451; BC201203281 . That kind of assessment is impressionistic. It involves more than mere acceptance of the apparent arguability, or even the good faith, of the plaintiff’s claim. But it does not require the court to undertake a probability assessment of the individual components of the claim: Johnstone v NSW [2006] NSWCA 105; BC200603588 at [23] . The fact that the proceedings fall outside the jurisdiction of the District Court does not preclude the exercise of the power to transfer proceedings to the Supreme Court. Conversely, the absence of jurisdiction may be relied on to avoid the application of the restrictive monetary limits that would otherwise apply: KBRV Resort Operations Pty Ltd (t/as Kingfisher Bay Resort & Village) v Chilcott (2001) 51 NSWLR 516 at 526; [2001] NSWCA 116; BC200102124 .

level.toc-caption: [s 140.15] Examples of proceedings where transfer made

heading.title: Examples of proceedings where transfer made

p.text: The following are examples of cases where actions have been removed:

where there are concurrent proceedings in two courts and the proceedings in the lower court may give rise to an issue estoppel affecting the proceedings pending in the higher (ie, the proposed transferee) court: Ritchie v Gumley (1954) 55 SR (NSW) 334; 72 WN (NSW) 298 ; Re Murray; Ex parte Hillman [1961] NSWR 573; (1961) 78 WN (NSW) 726 ; Re Australian General Disinfectant Co Pty Ltd; Ex parte Hancock [1968] 2 NSWR 772; (1968) 88 WN (NSW) 176 ;

where the damages are likely to exceed the lower court’s jurisdictional limits, especially where the risk has become apparent since the commencement of the proceedings: Ex parte Weissberger; Re Krejzar [1961] NSWR 912; (1960) 77 WN (NSW) 671 ; Ex parte O'Flynn; Re George Pearse Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 91 ; Ex parte Delponte; Re Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1468 ; Kadic v Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1967] 2 NSWR 257 at 258; (1967) 67 SR (NSW) 411 at 412 (applicant should demonstrate the probability of exceeding the jurisdictional limit);
where there are significant procedural advantages in the transferee court: Ex parte Heiliger (1897) 13 WN (NSW) 170 (the availability of evidence being taken on commission overseas);

where the proceedings involve complex and important issues of law or fact: Longbottom v Longbottom (1852) 8 Exch 203; 155 ER 1320 (bequest by will); Potter v Great Western Colliery Co Ltd (1894) 10 TLR 380 (negligence and expert evidence); Donkin v Pearson [1911] 2 KB 412 (right of a trade union to sue or be sued, whether trade union an unlawful combination by reason of its objects being in restraint of trade); Clavering v Conduit Mead Co [1941] 1 All ER 30 (first time Act construed, large claim, expert evidence); Ex parte Dusmanovic [1967] 2 NSWR 125; (1967) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 642 (important issues of equitable principle);
where the proceedings involve allegations of significant notoriety or public importance: Simpson v Shaw (1886) 56 LJQB 92; 56 LT 24; and

where the proceedings in one court may give rise to issue estoppel in proceedings in the other court: Ryner Pty Ltd v Roller [2007] NSWSC 372; BC200702781 at [13] (proceedings in District Court for money claim to be heard before proceedings in Supreme Court for possession of land — issue estoppel may be created in favour of successful party in District Court).

level.toc-caption: [s 140.20] Examples of proceedings where transfer refused

heading.title: Examples of proceedings where transfer refused

p.text: In the following cases the court refused to make an order:

where judgment has been entered in the proceedings: Ex parte Sabbatini; Re Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd [1970] 2 NSWR 24; (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 377 . Similarly, part heard proceedings will rarely be transferred: Kadic v Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1967] 2 NSWR 257 at 259; (1967) 67 SR (NSW) 411 at 414 ;

where the plaintiff had deliberately commenced proceedings in the lower court despite its jurisdictional limitation: Giusti Patents and Engineering Works Ltd v Maggs [1923] 1 Ch 515 : contrast General Estates Co v Beaver [1912] 2 KB 398 (proceedings mistakenly remitted to the lower court despite its jurisdictional limitation);

where a plaintiff-applicant had misconducted or delayed the proceedings to the detriment of the opposing party: Ex parte Delponte; Re Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1468 ; Luchko v Nguyen (NSWSC, Greenwood M, No 13904/96, 25 November 1996, unreported, BC9606107);

where there were concurrent proceedings in both courts but they involved different parties and had material differences in factual issues: Harbourside Catering Pty Ltd v TMG Development Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 631; BC200604951 ; United Card Services Pty Ltd v Object Consulting Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 743; BC201004664 (Local Court proceedings — delay in making the application, no evidence of lack of jurisdiction — no res judicata or issue estoppel if Local Court proceedings determined first).

where there were concurrent proceedings between the same parties in both courts but the matters were not sufficiently connected to be brought into one set of proceedings: Tadros v J & R Investment Services Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 63; BC200800484 at [14] and [15] ;
where there were conflicting decisions in the lower court: Fox v Ashwin (No 2) (1887) 4 WN (NSW) 78;

where the amounts in issue were modest and transfer was likely to increase costs unnecessarily: Trilogy Corporate Solutions Pty Ltd v Fitzroy Shopfitting and Building Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1026; BC200607793 (removal from District Court to the Supreme Court was sought in order to enliven provisions under cross-vesting legislation to allow consolidation of NSW and Victorian proceedings in NSW Supreme Court — no risk of inconsistent judgments in the proceedings);

where there was no demonstrable advantage to proceedings being conducted in the higher court, even though the proceedings involved the credibility of a solicitor: Ex parte McIntosh; Re Frey (1958) 75 WN (NSW) 519 per Else-Mitchell J.

where the proceedings involve a statutory jurisdiction conferred only on the District or Local Court: Rinbac Pty Ltd v Owners Corp Strata Plan 64972 (2010) 77 NSWLR 601; [2010] NSWSC 656; BC201004121 (appeal proceedings under s 200 of the Strata Scheme Management Act 1996).

Either party may apply for removal and it is not material that the party seeking removal invoked the jurisdiction of the District Court and assented to its exercise: Ex parte O'Flynn; Re George Pearse Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 91 , per Wallace J confirmed on appeal in George Pearse Pty Ltd v O'Flynn [1963] NSWR 102; [1962] SR (NSW) 400 .

Terms may be imposed on the transfer of the proceedings. Terms may include a restriction on the recovery of any additional costs attributable to the conduct of proceedings in the transferee court: Palmer v Whitfield (1867) 7 SCR (NSW) 21 (transfer after two trials, and consequential appeals, proceedings transferred on defendant’s application); Donkin v Pearson [1911] 2 KB 412 (trade union defendant applicant — impecunious plaintiff); Ex parte Delponte; Re Thiess Bros Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1468 (plaintiff applicant). Such terms may also include the payment of outstanding costs orders and the payment of costs incurred up to the transfer: Ryner Pty Ltd v Roller [2007] NSWSC 372; BC200702781 (defendant to pay outstanding costs from consent order and to pay the plaintiff’s costs in the District Court proceedings until the transfer of proceedings to the Supreme Court).

Where proceedings have been properly commenced in the District Court and are subsequently transferred to the Supreme Court because the likely damages will exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court, a plaintiff should not suffer any loss of priority as a result of the transfer of proceedings: Callanan v Lithgow Valley Colliery Co Ltd (NSWSC, Sharpe J, 8 December 1989, unreported). This general proposition is, however, subject to any procedural directions appropriate to the proper conduct of the transferred proceedings: Ryner Pty Ltd v Roller [2007] NSWSC 372; BC200702781 at [28] (addition of parties to the transferred proceedings).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 141] s 141 Transfer orders (cf Act No 9 1973, section 145; Act No 11 1970, section 21B)

leg:heading.title: Transfer orders (cf Act No 9 1973, section 145; Act No 11 1970, section 21B)

p.text: A transfer order takes effect when it is made.
A transfer order does not invalidate any order made or other thing done in the proceedings before the order was made.
[subs (2) am Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2[5], effective 28 January 2008]
Any order made by the lower court may be varied or revoked by an order of the higher court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 142] s 142 Stay of proceedings in lower court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 146; Act No 11 1970, section 21C)

leg:heading.title: Stay of proceedings in lower court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 146; Act No 11 1970, section 21C)

p.text: The higher court may make an order for a stay of proceedings in respect of which an application for a transfer order has been made.
Subsection (1) does not limit the power of the lower court to adjourn or stay the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 143] s 143 Proceedings after transfer (cf Act No 11 1970, section 21E; DCR Part 5, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings after transfer (cf Act No 11 1970, section 21E; DCR Part 5, rule 12)

p.text: Subject to the rules of court applicable in the higher court, any proceedings with respect to which a transfer order takes effect are to be continued in the higher court:
as if the proceedings had been duly commenced in the higher court on the date on which they were commenced in the lower court, and
as if any cross-claim in the proceedings had been duly made in the higher court on the date on which it was made in the lower court.
For the purposes of any proceedings continued in the higher court:

any abandonment of an amount under section 23 ceases to have effect except to the extent to which the amount originally claimed in the proceedings, or in any cross-claim in the proceedings, exceeded the jurisdictional limit of the higher court, and
any admission duly made in the lower court is to be treated as if it had been duly made in the higher court.
Subject to the rules of court applicable in the higher court, the power of the higher court to make orders as to costs includes a power to make orders with respect to the costs of:
the application for, and the making of, the transfer order, and
any step taken in the proceedings before the transfer order was made.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 144] s 144 Transfer of certain proceedings from District Court to Supreme Court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 147)

leg:heading.title: Transfer of certain proceedings from District Court to Supreme Court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 147)

p.text: This section applies to proceedings under Subdivision 2 of Division 8 of Part 3 of the District Court Act 1973.

If, during proceedings to which this section applies, the District Court decides that it lacks, or may lack, jurisdiction to hear and dispose of the proceedings, the District Court must order that the proceedings be transferred to the Supreme Court.
Proceedings that are transferred to the Supreme Court under subsection (2):
are to be continued in the Supreme Court:
as if the proceedings had been duly commenced in the Supreme Court on the date on which they were commenced in the District Court, and
as if any cross-claim in the proceedings had been duly made in the Supreme Court on the date on which it was made in the District Court, or
if the Supreme Court so orders, are to be remitted to the District Court and continued in the District Court as if they had not been transferred.

The District Court has, and may exercise, jurisdiction to hear and dispose of proceedings the subject of an order by the Supreme Court under subsection (3)(b), including such jurisdiction as is necessary to determine any question arising in any such proceedings.

If, during proceedings to which this section applies, the District Court decides that it is appropriate to do so for any reason other than the reason referred to in subsection (2), the District Court may order that the proceedings be transferred to the Supreme Court.
Proceedings that are transferred to the Supreme Court under subsection (5), are to be continued in the Supreme Court:
as if the proceedings had been duly commenced in the Supreme Court on the date on which they were commenced in the District Court, and
as if any cross-claim in the proceedings had been duly made in the Supreme Court on the date on which it was made in the District Court.
Subject to the rules of court applicable in the Supreme Court, the power of the Supreme Court to make orders as to costs includes a power to make orders with respect to the costs of:
the application for, and the making of, an order under subsection (2) or (5) , and
any step taken in the proceedings before an order under subsection (2) or (5) was made.
[subs (7) am Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2[6], effective 28 January 2008]
The making of an order under subsection (2) or (5) does not invalidate any order previously made by the District Court in the proceedings.
